title.native: 機動戦士ガンダム

description:
What would you do if you suddenly found yourself in the middle of a war? Teenager Amuro Ray sees his life shattered when war comes to his home. During the chaos, Amuro finds himself inside the mobile suit Gundam, the Earth Federation's new secret weapon, and he somehow gets it to work. Amuro and the other refugees flee their homeland on the warship White Base. This group of children and inexperienced soldiers will change the outcome of the war.

(Source: Sunrise)

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Space
tags.description: Partly or completely set in outer space.

tags.name: Space Opera
tags.description: Centers around space warfare, advanced technology, chivalric romance and adventure.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Tanks
tags.description: Prominently features the use of tanks or other armoured vehicles.

tags.name: Aviation
tags.description: Regarding the flying or operation of aircraft.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Revenge
tags.description: Prominently features a character who aims to exact punishment in a resentful or vindictive manner.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Environmental
tags.description: Concern with the state of the natural world and how humans interact with it.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Desert
tags.description: Prominently features a desert environment.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Time Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features time-traveling or other time-warping phenomena.

name.native: イセリナ・エッシェンバッハ

node.description:
[Website](http://www.yatate.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yatate_hajime) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/矢立肇) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajime_Yatate)

Hajime Yatate is a collective pseudonym for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s staff.

An animator turned mangaka, Yasuhiko was born in Hokkaido in December 1947, he dropped out of Hirosaki University in 1970 to work for MushiPro as an animator. In the 70s he became a freelancer and worked on TV anime. Some of his most famous work as a character designer or director are "Space Battleship Yamato", "Brave Raideen", "Combattler V" and "Mobile Suit Gundam".

In 1979, he made his debut as a mangaka with "Arion" serialized in the newly founded magazine "Ryu". Following this, Yasuhiko alternated between the Anime and Manga worlds with works like "Kiba - The Legend of White Fang", "Crusher Joe", and "Giant Gorg", and "Star of the Kurds", "C-Court", and "Venus Wars".

These worlds would overlap, when his manga "Arion" would get adapted into an anime film in 1986 with the title "Neo Heroic Fantasia: Arion". Following this, he would adapt his SF Military Chronicle "Venus Wars" into an anime film in 1989. The anime film adaptation for "Venus Wars" came at an unfortunate point for Yasuhiko, and the film was sealed, preventing it from being made readily available on home video formats in Japan (though still made accessible overseas). He turned to manga completely and had gained a respectable reputation as a history mangaka with works focusing on both Japanese history with "Jinmu", "Namuji", "Yamato Takeru" and European history with "Alexandros", "Joan", and Theology with "Jesus".

In 2001 he adapted the First Gundam anime into a manga with "Mobile Suit Gundam: The Origin" and was colossally popular, being serialized for 24 Tankoban volumes.

With over 50 years worth of experience across multiple mediums of entertainment and showing no signs of stopping, Yasuhiko's terrific worldview continues to touch the hearts of many around the world.

In 1981, he won the Seiun Award in the Art category. In 1992, he received the Japan Cartoonists Association Award for his work "Namuji". From 1979 to 1982, he ranked first in the Anime Grand Prix for Character Design. In 2000, he won the Japan Media Arts Festival Excellence Prize in the Manga category for "Ōdō no Inu". In 2012, he won the Seiun Award in the Best Comic category for "Mobile Suit Gundam: The Origin". In 2015, he received the Animation Kobe Special Award.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/富野由悠季) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshiyuki_Tomino)

Yoshiyuki Tomino is an anime creator best known for creating the Gundam anime franchise.

Began his career in 1963 with [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/)'s company, [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/), scripting and directing episodes of the first Japanese anime television series, [Astro Boy](https://anilist.co/anime/2747/). He later became one of the most important members of the anime studio [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), going on to direct numerous anime through the '70s, '80s and '90s. He is perhaps best known for his transformation of the "Super Robot" mecha anime genre into the "Real Robot" genre with 1979's [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/), the first in the Gundam franchise.

Known for using numerous pseudonyms.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/富野由悠季) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshiyuki_Tomino)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/富野由悠季) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshiyuki_Tomino)

(Source: Wikipedia)

Originating from [Tatsunoko Production](https://anilist.co/studio/103/).
Kunio Okawara was the first in the industry to be specifically credited as a mechanical designer. He is the designer of numerous Real Robots and Super Robots.

Ichirou Itano is a Japanese director, producer, animator and mechanical designer. He has worked in a number of science fiction anime series, especially mecha-themed ones. Director of works such as [Angel Cop](https://anilist.co/anime/1351/), [Battle Royal High School](https://anilist.co/anime/3625/), [Gantz](https://anilist.co/anime/384/) and more.

Itano is best known among anime fans for a style of action scene that he developed, usually nicknamed "Itano Circus" by fans; it refers to a highly stylized and acrobatic method of depicting aerial combat and dogfights in many anime.

The production in [Space Runaway Ideon](https://anilist.co/anime/930/) became a hot topic in the anime industry, and it came to be called this by comparing the brisk movement of mechanics to the air acrobatics of the circus. The technique became more famous when Itano used it for the "dogfights" depicted in [The Super Dimension Fortress Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) anime TV series in 1982. It's characterized by detailed, fluid shading of the mecha, the close-range acrobatic moves the dueling fighters make in combat, as well as twisting contrails left by fighters and missiles. It is also commonly used in specific reference to an attack where a mecha or spaceship launches a large swarm of guided missiles with meticulously animated spiraling smoke trails and erratic trajectories and its target is repeatedly dodging those missiles at a high speed.

According to him, [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Masami Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/129865/) and [Yasushi Muraki](https://anilist.co/staff/105090/) are the only animators to have fully mastered Itano Circus.

Ichirou Itano is a Japanese director, producer, animator and mechanical designer. He has worked in a number of science fiction anime series, especially mecha-themed ones. Director of works such as [Angel Cop](https://anilist.co/anime/1351/), [Battle Royal High School](https://anilist.co/anime/3625/), [Gantz](https://anilist.co/anime/384/) and more.

Itano is best known among anime fans for a style of action scene that he developed, usually nicknamed "Itano Circus" by fans; it refers to a highly stylized and acrobatic method of depicting aerial combat and dogfights in many anime.

The production in [Space Runaway Ideon](https://anilist.co/anime/930/) became a hot topic in the anime industry, and it came to be called this by comparing the brisk movement of mechanics to the air acrobatics of the circus. The technique became more famous when Itano used it for the "dogfights" depicted in [The Super Dimension Fortress Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) anime TV series in 1982. It's characterized by detailed, fluid shading of the mecha, the close-range acrobatic moves the dueling fighters make in combat, as well as twisting contrails left by fighters and missiles. It is also commonly used in specific reference to an attack where a mecha or spaceship launches a large swarm of guided missiles with meticulously animated spiraling smoke trails and erratic trajectories and its target is repeatedly dodging those missiles at a high speed.

According to him, [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Masami Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/129865/) and [Yasushi Muraki](https://anilist.co/staff/105090/) are the only animators to have fully mastered Itano Circus.

A highly prolific and an extremely influential animator.

Know for his experimentation with the timing of keyframes, his dynamic poses, and his peculiar effects Kanada pioneered a number of techniques and concepts that permeated and shaped the Japanese animation industry, influencing not only his peers but also the generations to come.

Kanada's ability and his tendency to be very personal with his drawings, even to the point of ignoring storyboards if the situation required, popularized in the industry the concept of letting the individual animator's talents shine instead of being uniformed into anonymity. This precept is still respected today and it's one of the reasons Japanese animation is so distinctly unique. His career is also a testament to his ethos that expressive and vibrant animation is not achieved simply through increasing the number of frames but through playing with movement, poses and timing.

In the early '00s, Kanada became an employee at Square Enix.

Notable Square Enix titles in which he was credited:

~!
- 2002, Final Fantasy XI (Motion Capture, Animation Director)
- 2005, Musashiden II: Blade Master (Storyboard)
- 2006, Dawn of Mana (Facial Setting)
- 2007, Final Fantasy 4 DS Version (Storyboard)
- 2009, Final Fantasy XIII (Storyboard Director) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2011, Final Fantasy XIII-2 (Storyboard) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2012, Dragon Quest X (Storyboard)  - *Posthumous credit.* !~

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%98%9F%E5%B1%B1%E5%8D%9A%E4%B9%8B)

Hiroyuki Hoshiyama was a renown screenwriter. He started his career in [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/) in 1967, but left it later in 1973 and worked as a freelancer until his passing.
He was a music composer for anime, drama and jidaigeki from Tokyo, Japan. He passed away from renal failure.

He was active in the 70s, 80s and the first half of 90s. In Transformers he wrote some episodes of The Headmasters, Super-God Masterforce, and Victory. Outside of Transformers, he wrote episodes for other giant mecha shows such as Mobile Suit Gundam, Daitarn 3, Xabungle and the second Tetsujin 28 show (aka New Gigantor), as well as non-mecha anime.

(Source: AniDB)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/富野由悠季) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshiyuki_Tomino)
